name.text: 37.2.3.3 Choosing randomly an answer in an exam

questiontext.text:
Exercise

An examination consists of {@n_questions@} multi-choice questions, in each of which a candidate has to deduce which one of {@n_choices@} suggested answers is correct. A completely unprepared student guesses each answer completely randomly. What is the probability that this student gets {@n_correct_ans@} or more questions correct?

[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]

Note: round your answer to 5 decimal places. Include additional zero(s) if your answer is exact with a lower number of decimal places.

generalfeedback.text:
SOLUTION:

Let \(X\) be a random variable ‘number of answers guessed correctly’ then for each question (i.e. trial) the probability of a ‘success’ = \(\dfrac{1}{{@n_choices@}}\). It is clear that \(X\) follows a binomial distribution with \(n={@n_questions@}\) and \(p={@1/n_choices@}\).

\(\text{P}\) (randomly choosing correct answer) \(=\dfrac{1}{{@n_choices@}}\qquad n={@n_questions@}\) 

\[\begin{aligned} \text{P} ({@n_correct_ans@}\ \text{or more correct})&=\text{P} [(X={@n_correct_ans@})\cup (X={@n_correct_ans+1@})\cup (X={@n_correct_ans+2@})]\\ &=\ ^{{@n_questions@}}\!C_{@n_correct_ans@}\left(\dfrac{1}{{@n_choices@}}\right)^{@n_correct_ans@}\left(\dfrac{@n_choices-1@}{@n_choices@}\right)^2+\ ^{{@n_questions@}}\!C_{@n_correct_ans+1@}\left(\dfrac{1}{{@n_choices@}}\right)^{@n_correct_ans+1@}\left(\dfrac{{@n_choices-1@}}{{@n_choices@}}\right)+\ ^{{@n_questions@}}\!C_{{@n_questions@}}\left(\dfrac{1}{{@n_choices@}}\right)^{{@n_questions@}} \\ & ={@dispdp(ta,5)@}\end{aligned}\]
